questions.text: A concerned father brings his 8-year-old son, Dev, to the pediatric clinic after noticing his frequent complaints of bone pain and a recent incident where a minor fall resulted in a fracture. During the examination, the pediatrician observes multiple healing fractures of varying ages on the X-rays, along with noticeable bruises on the skin. Initially, there is a suspicion of non-accidental injury, but further assessment reveals Dev has a short stature, distinctive blue sclera, and visible bone deformities in his limbs and spine. These findings suggest a genetic condition affecting bone strength rather than external trauma. What is the pattern of inheritance for Dev's diagnosed condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Autosomal Dominant

 

Explanation:

 

The diagnosis based on the David’s history is Osteogenesis imperfecta and it is Autosomal Dominant in nature.

 

The clinical features include

  • Multiple fractures: recurrent fractures, which can occur with minimal or no trauma. Can cause deformities or shortening of limbs.
  • Blue sclera: Its due to the underlying connective tissue abnormalities.
  • Dental problems: Brittle teeth that break easily or wear down quickly. (Dentinogenesis imperfecta - The bluish, opalescent sheen on several teeth results from genetically defective dentin).
  • Hearing loss: Hearing loss occurs in approximately 20% of young children and as many as 50% of adults by the age of 50
  • Skeletal deformities: scoliosis (curvature of the spine), kyphosis (hunchback), or pectus excavatum (sunken chest).
  • Short stature: due to the impact of skeletal abnormalities on bone growth.
  • Easy bruising: Osteogenesis imperfecta can cause easy bruising or bleeding, particularly in people with severe forms of the condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of frequent fractures from minimal trauma, blue sclera, short stature, and bone deformities, strongly suggests Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI). OI is a genetic disorder primarily affecting collagen, leading to brittle bones and a susceptibility to fractures. The majority of OI cases are inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, meaning a single copy of the defective gene from either parent can cause the disorder.

Note - Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) (brittle bone disease) is the most common genetic cause of osteoporosis.

 

Ref: nelson 21st Edition – Page No-14415-14427

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the pediatric clinic by their mother, who is concerned about the child's noticeably shorter stature compared to peers. Upon examination, the pediatrician notes that the child's short stature appears disproportionate, with a more significant discrepancy between the upper and lower body segments. Considering a potential diagnosis of a condition affecting growth, the pediatrician decides to assess the child's body proportions more closely by measuring the upper segment and lower segment ratios. Understanding the normal progression of body proportions from childhood to adulthood is crucial in this assessment. At what age do the upper and lower segments of the body typically reach adult proportions?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 10 years

 

Option D:

 

Upper segment lower segment ratio:

Upper segment — vertex to pubic symphysis

Lower segment — pubic symphysis to heel

 

Normal Values

Birth—1.7:1

3 years—1.3:1

7 years - 1:1

In adults the ratio is: 0.9:1

So, the best answer according to the options is D

 

Explanation:

 

Option A- By the age of 2 years the ratio is 1.4:1

 

Option C- By the age of 7 years the ratio is 1:1 whereas the adult ratio is 0.9:1

 

Educational Objective:

 

The upper-to-lower body segment ratio (U/L ratio) provides an assessment of truncal growth relative to limb growth. The lower-body segment is defined as the length from the top of the symphysis pubis to the floor, and the upper-body segment is the total height minus the lower-body segment.

The U/L ratio equals approximately 1.7 at birth, 1.3 at 3 year, and 1.0 after 7 year. Higher U/L ratios are characteristic of short-limb dwarfism, as occurs with Turner syndrome or bone disorders, whereas lower ratios suggest hypogonadism or Marfan syndrome.

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 43-51; Nelson 21st Ed Pg 1183

choices.text: Fragile x syndrome

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is being evaluated for short stature. During the evaluation, several distinct physical features are noted: a webbed neck, downward-slanting palpebral fissures, cubitus valgus, pectus carinatum superiorly, and a shield-like chest. An echocardiogram reveals cardiovascular abnormalities. Interestingly, similar clinical features are observed in her brother. What is the most probable diagnosis considering the clinical features and the fact that both siblings are affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Noonan syndrome

 

Option C.

 

Noonan syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition, seen both in males and females.

Present with same features of turner syndrome.

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Short stature
  • Tall forehead
  • Shield chest
  • Webbed neck
  • Wide spread nipples
  • Pectus carinatum superiorly and
  • Cubitus valgus

 

Associated anomalies:

 

  • CVS: Pulmonary valve stenosis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, ASD, VSD.
  • Gonads: male has small penis and cryptorchidism, whereas females are normal and fertile.
  • Bleeding disorders; leukemia.

 

Diagnosis:

 

USG of kidney is done to screen abnormalities.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Turner syndrome: Primarily affects females and is characterized by the presence of a single X chromosome. The features described fit Turner syndrome, but its occurrence in a male sibling (as in the brother mentioned) rules out this condition.

 

Option B. Klinefelter syndrome: Affects males and is characterized by an extra X chromosome (47, XXY). The clinical features mentioned do not align with Klinefelter syndrome, and it would not explain the sister's presentation.

 

Option D. Fragile X syndrome: Primarily associated with intellectual disability (low IQ), behavioural challenges, and certain physical traits, but not typically presenting with the cardiovascular and skeletal features described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Noonan syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by Noonan facies (hypertelorism, ptosis, short neck, low-set ears), short stature, congenital heart disease, and multiple skeletal and hematologic abnormalities.

 

Noonan syndrome can affect both males and females, which is consistent with the brother also exhibiting similar features.

 

It is primarily an autosomal dominant disorder composed of multiple genetic types. Heterozygous mutations in PTPN11 cause about 50% of Noonan cases. Other cases are caused by mutations in other RAS pathway associated genes such as KRAS, SOS1 , and NRAS. Autosomal recessive forms have also been identified due to mutations of SHOC2 or CBL.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st edition, Chapter 601– Page No 11714-11716

choices.text: Prader Willi syndrome
Di George syndrome

questions.text: A worried mother brought her 5-year-old girl child to the pediatric OPD with complaints of her constant feeling of hunger. Her mother mentions that she is obese than everyone in her class. On evaluation she has a short stature, intellectual disability and the following appearance. While asking her history in the past, her mother reminded that she had a feeding difficulty at birth as she was hypotonic and she had this voracious appetite from age of 2. Her mother was concerned about her future and asks you to diagnose her. What is the most probable diagnosis you will make and convey to her mother?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prader Willi syndrome

 

Option B.

 

The diagnosis based on the clinical feature and the image is Prader Willi syndrome.

Genomic Imprinting:15q11-microdeletion of paternal side or inheritance of both copies from maternal side.

Clinical features:

  • Short stature (responsive to growth hormone)
  • Intellectually disability
  • Hypotonia
  • Small hand and feet
  • Obesity
  • Hyperphagia (ghrelin increased).
  • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Angelman syndrome: Characterized by severe intellectual disability, lack of speech, seizures, and a happy demeanor, but not typically associated with obesity or the described feeding pattern.

 

Option C. DiGeorge syndrome: Associated with congenital heart defects, immune deficiencies, and cleft palate, among other symptoms, but not typically presenting with obesity and excessive hunger.

 

Option D. Williams syndrome: Known for hypercalcemia, cardiovascular issues, unique cognitive profile, and very social personality, Williams syndrome does not typically involve the described pattern of early-life feeding difficulties followed by excessive appetite and obesity.

 

Educational objective:

 

The history of hypotonia, feeding difficulties in infancy, followed by excessive appetite and obesity, alongside intellectual challenges (mental retardation), hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, aligns with Prader-Willi syndrome. (15q11 deletion)

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No 625, 3058

choices.text: Growth hormone deficiency

questions.text: A 3-year-old child, accompanied by his parents, visits your clinic for a consultation. Upon observation, it's noted that all family members share a similar short stature, which has been a characteristic trait since birth. The parents express their past experiences of discrimination due to their stature but also acknowledge a shift towards acceptance in society. They wish to prevent their child from facing similar challenges and seek your advice. After conducting a thorough examination, you identify limb shortening and disproportionate short stature in the child, indicative of an inherited defect in enchondral ossification linked to an FGFR3 mutation. You inform the parents that the condition is genetic and explain the limitations regarding its alteration. Based on the family history and clinical evaluation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Achondroplasia

 

Option B:

  • Achondroplasia is AD disorder because of mutation in FGFR3 gene,
  • it leads to abnormal enchondral ossification.
  • Rizhomelic limb shortening
  • Disproportionate short stature
  • Champagne glass pelvis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Osteogenesis imperfecta – will result in short stature but the history will suggest the multiple fractures, blue sclera, skin and skeletal abnormalities.

 

Option C and D.  Both of them will result in proportionate short stature and is less common in familial cases of AD inheritance.

 

Educational objective:

 

Achondroplasia is the most common form of dwarfism characterized by disproportionate short stature, particularly noticeable in the limbs. It is caused by mutations in the FGFR3 gene, which leads to abnormal cartilage formation and enchondral ossification during bone development. This condition is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter – 721 Page No 14374-79

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric outpatient department by her mother due to concerns about her short stature. During the evaluation, the physician notes several distinctive features: a webbed neck, a low posterior hairline, and a dislocated patella. Given the clinical presentation suggestive of a genetic anomaly, karyotyping is performed, and the findings are shown in the accompanying image. Based on the history and karyotyping results, what is the most probable diagnosis, and what management options should be considered?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Turner syndrome; reassurance

 

Option B.

 

As itâ€™s a case of Turners syndrome laparoscopic gonadectomy is recommended for the increased risk of gonadoblastoma  in cases of 45 XO/46 XY due to presence of Y chromosome has increased risk of gonadoblastoma.

 

Turner syndrome:

 

Clinical features-

  • Short stature

  • Shield chest

  • Webbed neck

  • Wide spread nipples and

  • Short fourth metacarpal

 

Associated anomalies-

  • CVS : coarctation of aorta, bicuspid aortic valve

  • Renal: horse shoe kidney.

  • Gonads: gonadal dysgenesis, gonadoblastoma.

  • Strabismus

  • Cataract.

 

Diagnosis:

  • Ultrasound pelvis reveals hypoplastic uterus and streak ovaries.

  • Karyotype is indicated in all turner syndrome to exclude presence of Y chromosome (associated with gonadoblastoma).

  • Echocardiography and ultrasound for kidney for screening of cardiac and renal abnormalities.

  • Managements:

  • GH therapy (0.1-0.15unit/kg/day)

  • Patients with Y chromosome mosaicism â€“laparoscopic gonadectomy is recommended.

 

Note: phenotypic females with 45XO/46XY mosaicism have 15-30% risk of developing gonadoblastoma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A and Option C. Klinefelter syndrome is seen in boys with karyotype 47XXY and they will have tall stature instead of short stature in turnerâ€™s syndrome.

 

Option D.  Laparoscopic gonadectomy in cases of 45 XO/46 XY due to presence of Y chromosome has increased risk of gonadoblastoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by the presence of a single X chromosome and the absence of all or part of a second sex chromosome in females, leading to various clinical manifestations, including short stature, webbed neck, low posterior hairline, and potential skeletal abnormalities such as a dislocated patella.

 

The recommendation for laparoscopic gonadectomy in Turner syndrome is specific to patients who have Y chromosome material, as they are at an increased risk for gonadoblastoma, a type of tumor that can develop in the dysgenetic gonads. Gonadectomy is an important preventive measure.

 

Ref: Essential pediatrics by OP Ghai 9Th Edition â€“ Page No-536-537

questions.text: During a health camp in a rural area, a paediatrician observes a 5-year-old child with unusual growth patterns. The child, accompanied by his parents, exhibits rapid height increase, thickened skin, and distinct facial features including a pronounced jaw, enlarged tongue, and broad nose. Concerned about the possibility of a hormonal imbalance, specifically gigantism due to excess growth hormone (GH) secretion by a pituitary tumor, the paediatrician decides to initiate a screening process. Which of the following tests should be ordered first to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. IGF1 levels

 

Option C:

 

The screening test of choice for increased GH levels is estimating the IGF1 levels

IGF-1 is a hormone found naturally in blood. Its main job is to manage the effects of growth hormone (GH) in body. Normal IGF-1 and GH functions include tissue and bone growth.

IGF-1 is formed in different tissues because of GH in the blood. Some disorders and diseases, such as pituitary tumors and gigantism, can cause your body to make too much GH. Because IGF-1 measurements relate to GH measurements, this test is used to diagnose many problems linked to too much or too little GH.

 

Clinical features of Gigantism are

 

  • Thick skin,
  • Large tongue,
  • Broad nose
  • Prognathism
  • Headache and visual field defects.

 

Treatment; Octreotide and Pegvisomat.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. GH levels: GH levels fluctuate significantly throughout the day, making them less reliable for initial screening. GH levels might still be necessary for diagnosis but after initial screening with IGF1 levels. GH levels will be increased in cases of both gigantism and Laron dwarfism.

 

Option B. Cortisol levels: Cortisol levels would be more indicative of adrenal function and could be relevant in conditions like Cushing's syndrome, not gigantism.

 

Option D. Prolactin levels: Elevated prolactin levels could indicate a prolactinoma, another type of pituitary tumor, but it's not directly related to the symptoms of gigantism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate initial screening test for suspected gigantism in children is Serum IGF-1 levels (Reliable indicator of sustained GH excess, making it the test of choice)

 

Ref: Ghai Essential Paediatrics 8th Edition, Page No-513.

questions.text: A mother, residing in a region where hypothyroidism is not endemic, brings her child to the clinic due to failure to thrive and delayed developmental milestones. The pediatric examination notes the child's hoarse cry, mottled skin, and distinct facial and abdominal features. Considering these clinical presentations, what is the most common cause of the child's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thyroid dysgenesis

 

Option B:

 

The clinical features and the image of a baby with umbilical hernia, large tongue and hypotonia are suggestive of Congenital hypothyroidism, the most common cause of Congenital hypothyroidism is Thyroid dysgenesis.

 

Untreated case may lead to

 

  • Intellectual disability
  • Disproportionate stature
  • Delayed bone maturation and
  • Delayed puberty.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Thyroid dyshormonogenesis is associated with positive family history in Congenital hypothyroidism cases.

 

Option C. Hashimoto's thyroiditis: This is an autoimmune condition leading to hypothyroidism, more common in older children and adults, and less likely in very young children presenting with congenital features.

 

Option D. Graves' disease: Graves disease is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism in adolescents and its symptoms would contrast with those described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thyroid dysgenesis is the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism, accounting for approximately 85% of cases. It includes a spectrum of developmental abnormalities such as ectopic thyroid tissue, hypoplastic thyroid gland, or complete absence of the gland. These developmental issues lead to insufficient thyroid hormone production, which is critical for growth and development, thus explaining the child's symptoms.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 581 Page No- 11398-11423

Ghai Essential Pediatrics 8th Edition, Page No-516-519.

questions.text: In a pediatric clinic, a 26-month-old child presents with unique facial characteristics such as doll-like facies, frontal bossing, and a depressed nasal bridge. The child, notably shorter than peers, has a proportionate body structure. An evaluation indicates a delayed bone age compared to the chronological age. Given these findings, which condition is least likely to account for the child's proportionate short stature?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Achondroplasia.

 

Option D:

 

Achondroplasia is a genetic disorder characterized by disproportionate dwarfism, typically presenting with short limbs relative to the trunk and specific craniofacial abnormalities. Given the child's proportionate short stature and the absence of limb disproportion, achondroplasia is the least likely cause among the options provided.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Growth Hormone Deficiency: This condition can lead to proportionate short stature due to a uniform reduction in growth velocity but would not typically result in the specific craniofacial features described.

 

Option B. Constitutional Delay: This common, benign condition can cause temporary proportionate short stature and delayed bone age, aligning with the child's presentation except for the distinct facial features.

 

Option C. Malnutrition: Chronic malnutrition can result in proportionate short stature and delayed bone age, but may not account for the specific facial characteristics observed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Achondroplasia

 

  • An AD disorder because of mutation in FGFR3 gene.
  • It leads to abnormal enchondral ossification.
  • Rizhomelic limb shortening
  • Disproportionate short stature
  • Champagne glass pelvis.

 

 

Ref; Nelson 21st Edition. Page 14368
